items.title: Trump’s new wave of tariffs, briefly explained
items.author: Cameron Peters
items.summary:
- President **Trump** is reintroducing tariffs on countries like *Japan* and *South Korea* due to perceived trade deficits. 
- He previously paused tariffs after market reactions, but few trade deals followed that period. 
- The future of these tariffs remains uncertain amidst market fluctuations and ongoing court cases regarding their legality.

items.title: The Astonishing Racism in NYC’s Mayoral Race
items.author: Abdallah Fayyad
items.summary:
- Zohran Mamdani's campaign has faced extreme *racist* attacks, highlighting a troubling trend in American politics.
- The rise of *Trumpism* and open bigotry has normalized hateful rhetoric against marginalized groups, including Muslims and immigrants.
- Mamdani’s experiences reflect a broader pattern of *Islamophobia* and *anti-Palestinian* racism that is prevalent in contemporary discourse.

items.title: Why were the central Texas floods so deadly?
items.author: Umair Irfan
items.summary:
- At least *90 lives* lost in central Texas due to recent floods, marking the deadliest event since Hurricane Harvey.
- A convergence of weather conditions, including *Tropical Storm Barry*, created severe storms that caused *torrential downpours*.
- Gaps in *communication systems* hampered warnings, with many residents unaware of evacuation needs until too late.

items.title: The US just recorded the most measles cases in 30 years
items.author: Dylan Scott
items.summary:
- The US has reported *1,277 measles cases* in 2025, marking the most severe outbreak since 1992.
- Despite a *decline in case growth*, the virus continues spreading, raising concerns amid summer activities.
- Vaccination remains the *most effective defense*, with calls for increased awareness and immunization amidst growing skepticism around vaccines.

items.title: Trump's Denaturalization Plans Target Citizens
items.author: Nicole Narea
items.summary:
- The Trump administration is renewing efforts to *denaturalize* US citizens, prioritizing individuals seen as threats to national security or with felony backgrounds.
- This strategy mirrors historical political repression, raising concerns about *due process* and targeting political dissent.
- Legal experts warn of *serious implications* for the rights of the 24.5 million naturalized citizens in the US, suggesting a dangerous precedent is being set.

items.title: Welcome to the July issue of The Highlight
items.author: Vox Staff
items.summary:
• The July issue explores the *challenges* of suburban growth and housing shortages.  
• It features diverse topics, including the *intellectual vibe shift* towards liberal ideas and advancements in IUD procedures.  
• Additional discussions cover AI's potential in *bioweapons* prevention and health concerns regarding microwaves.

items.title: Democrats’ Tea Party Moment Explained
items.author: Christian Paz
items.summary:
• The Democratic Party may be experiencing a *grassroots* movement similar to the Tea Party's impact on Republicans. 
• Key issues driving this change include discontent with current leadership and a desire for a more *progressive* agenda. 
• Upcoming primaries could see challenges to established Democrats as voters seek representation that prioritizes *working-class* concerns.

items.title: How Black Artists Are Reclaiming the American Flag
items.author: Jonquilyn Hill
items.summary:
- The American flag holds a *complex* significance for Black Americans, intertwined with *history and struggle*.  
- Many Black service members have fought for a country that has historically *excluded* them, highlighting a deep sense of *ownership* and sacrifice.  
- Contemporary Black artists like Beyoncé are reclaiming the flag, asserting that *progress* and *heritage* inspire a new, inclusive sense of patriotism.

items.title: Heart attacks aren’t as fatal as they used to be
items.author: Bryan Walsh
items.summary:
- The **death rate** from heart attacks has plummeted nearly 90% since 1970, now giving older patients a 90% survival chance.  
- Key advancements include **public health campaigns** against smoking, the development of **statins**, and improvements in **emergency care**.  
- However, around 700,000 Americans still die from heart disease annually, emphasizing the need for continued efforts in **prevention** and **screening**.

items.title: Is ChatGPT Killing Higher Education?
items.author: Sean Illing
items.summary:
- Increased *AI usage* by students leads to widespread *cheating* in higher education.
- Professors express *despair* over AI's impact, struggling to maintain educational standards.
- The situation raises significant questions about the *value* of college education and institutional adaptability.
